(1896). Nihongi, pp. 109. The Gukanshō ruled from the palace of Akitsushima-no-miya at Muro in what will come to be known as Yamato province.Brown, p. 251; Varley, p. 90. ==Traditional history== Kōan is almost certainly a legend. The Kojiki records only his name and genealogy. The Nihonshoki includes Kōan as the fifth of .Aston, pp. 145-146. Emperor Kōan was the second son of Emperor Kōshō. Jinnō Shōtōki records that his mother was Yosotarashi-no-hime, who was the daughter of Okitsuyoso, and ancestress of the Owari.Varley, p. 90. ==Events of Kōan's life== The absence of information about Kōan does not imply that no such person ever existed. Very little information is available for study prior to the reign of the 29th monarch, Emperor Kimmei.Titsingh, pp. 34-36; Brown, pp. 261-262; Varley, pp. 123-124. === After his death === This emperor's official name after his death (his posthumous name) was regularized many centuries after the lifetime which was ascribed to Kōan.Aston, pp. 145-146. The actual site of his grave is not known. According to the Imperial Household Agency, this emperor is venerated at a memorial Shinto shrine (misasagi) at Nara. ==Related pages== * Emperor of Japan * List of emperors of Japan * Japanese imperial family tree == References == Category:Emperors of Japan
